Introduction

An aquatic ecosystem is a community of living organisms interacting with water’s physical and chemical environment. It covers about 71% of Earth’s surface and includes freshwater and marine ecosystems.

1. Abiotic Components

Water

  • Medium for life
  • Transports nutrients
  • Regulates temperature

Light

  • Essential for photosynthesis
  • Photic and Aphotic zones
  • Controls productivity

Temperature

  • Affects metabolism
  • Thermal stratification in lakes
  • Impacts oxygen levels

Dissolved Gases & Nutrients

  • Oxygen, Carbon dioxide, Nitrogen
  • Nitrogen & Phosphorus support growth
  • Excess causes eutrophication

2. Biotic Components

Producers

Phytoplankton, algae, aquatic plants. Base of food chain and oxygen producers.

Consumers

  • Primary – Zooplankton
  • Secondary – Small fish, frogs
  • Tertiary – Sharks, dolphins

Decomposers

Bacteria and fungi recycle nutrients and maintain ecosystem balance.

3. Types of Aquatic Ecosystems

Freshwater Ecosystems

  • Lentic – Lakes & Ponds
  • Lotic – Rivers & Streams

Marine Ecosystems

  • Oceans
  • Coral Reefs
  • Estuaries
  • Mangroves

4. Food Chain

Phytoplankton → Zooplankton → Small Fish → Large Fish → Humans

Food webs are more complex and increase ecosystem stability.

5. Importance

  • Climate regulation
  • Food resources
  • Biodiversity support
  • Economic value

6. Human Impact

  • Water pollution
  • Overfishing
  • Plastic waste
  • Climate change

Conclusion

The Aquatic ecosystems are complex systems where abiotic and biotic components interact to sustain life. Protecting them is essential for environmental sustainability and human survival.
